articles.headline: Coming Soon to a Theater Near You. Very Soon.
articles.snippet: Hollywood’s top three marketers — Walt Disney Studios, Warner Bros. and Universal Pictures — say marathon marketing campaigns no longer make sense for most movies.
articles.abstract: Hollywood’s top three marketers — Walt Disney Studios, Warner Bros. and Universal Pictures — say marathon marketing campaigns no longer make sense for most movies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Conventional wisdom in Hollywood has long held that big, lumbering “tentpole” movies require protracted promotional campaigns.

articles.headline: For 50 Years Since Apollo 11, Presidents Have Tried to Take That Next Giant Leap
articles.snippet: President Trump is only the latest to propose returning to the moon and then heading to Mars. But he faces the burdens of history to accomplish what his predecessors could not.
articles.abstract: President Trump is only the latest to propose returning to the moon and then heading to Mars. But he faces the burdens of history to accomplish what his predecessors could not.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At his star-spangled Independence Day extravaganza this month, President Trump singled out Gene Kranz, the legendary Apollo flight director. “Gene,” the president said, “I want you to know that we’re going to be back on the moon very soon — and someday soon, we will plant the American flag on Mars.”

articles.headline: Trump’s Labor Pick Has Defended Corporations, and One Killer Whale
articles.snippet: Eugene Scalia, whom Mr. Trump plans to nominate as labor secretary, has been a go-to lawyer for businesses like UPS and SeaWorld.
articles.abstract: Eugene Scalia, whom Mr. Trump plans to nominate as labor secretary, has been a go-to lawyer for businesses like UPS and SeaWorld.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eugene Scalia, whom President Trump intends to nominate as labor secretary, is often hired by companies when they are sued by workers, or when they want to push back against new employment laws and regulations.

articles.headline: Equifax Is Said to Be Close to Reaching Deal in Huge ’17 Data Breach
articles.snippet: The agreement, which calls for the company to pay around $650 million, is meant to resolve federal and state inquiries and consumer claims over the exposure of data of at least 145 million people.
articles.abstract: The agreement, which calls for the company to pay around $650 million, is meant to resolve federal and state inquiries and consumer claims over the exposure of data of at least 145 million people.
articles.lead_paragraph: The credit bureau Equifax is expected to pay around $650 million to settle federal and state investigations and consumer claims relating to a data breach that exposed sensitive information belonging to at least 145 million people, according to two people familiar with the settlement discussions.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: A New Red Scare Is Reshaping Washington
articles.snippet: A long-defunct Cold War group has come back to life to warn of the dangers of China. They also risk triggering a new Red Scare.
articles.abstract: A long-defunct Cold War group has come back to life to warn of the dangers of China. They also risk triggering a new Red Scare.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a ballroom across from the Capitol building, an unlikely group of military hawks, populist crusaders, Chinese Muslim freedom fighters and followers of the Falun Gong has been meeting to warn anyone who will listen that China poses an existential threat to the United States that will not end until the Communist Party is overthrown.

articles.headline: Trump Employs an Old Tactic: Using Race for Gain
articles.snippet: Since well before setting off a furor by telling four Democratic lawmakers of color to “go back” to their home countries, President Trump has sought to turn racial divisions to his advantage.
articles.abstract: Since well before setting off a furor by telling four Democratic lawmakers of color to “go back” to their home countries, President Trump has sought to turn racial divisions to his advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the fourth season of “The Apprentice,” Donald J. Trump searched for a gimmick to bolster ratings. His idea was simple if explosive — pit an all-white team against an all-black team.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Michael M. Grynbaum, Maggie Haberman, Annie Karni and Russ Buettner

articles.headline: For Boris Johnson’s Clan, Blood Is Thicker Than Political Conviction
articles.snippet: Cast as something between the Kennedys and the Kardashians, the relatives of the pro-Brexit juggernaut likely to become the next U.K. prime minister don’t always share his views.
articles.abstract: Cast as something between the Kennedys and the Kardashians, the relatives of the pro-Brexit juggernaut likely to become the next U.K. prime minister don’t always share his views.
articles.lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Boris Johnson, the pro-Brexit human juggernaut who is likely to become the next prime minister of Britain, declared that British immigrants should be required to learn English.  In some parts of the country, he complained, “English is not spoken by some people as their first language.”

articles.headline: Chinese Money in the U.S. Dries Up as Trade War Drags On
articles.snippet: Tougher regulations and uncertainty about tariffs have made America less friendly for foreign investment.
articles.abstract: Tougher regulations and uncertainty about tariffs have made America less friendly for foreign investment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Growing distrust between the United States and China has slowed the once steady flow of Chinese cash into America, with Chinese investment plummeting by nearly 90 percent since President Trump took office.

articles.headline: In 88 Trips to Capitol Hill, Mueller Grew Weary of Partisanship
articles.snippet: Dozens of hours of Robert S. Mueller III’s congressional testimony since 1990 reveal his complex relationship with legislators.
articles.abstract: Dozens of hours of Robert S. Mueller III’s congressional testimony since 1990 reveal his complex relationship with legislators.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Days after he was appointed special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III visited the Capitol to meet with members of the Senate Judiciary Committee, which was conducting its own Russia investigation and needed to coordinate with his. Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa and the committee’s chairman, came with a wisecrack.

articles.headline: A Peculiarly Dutch Summer Rite: Children Let Loose in the Night Woods
articles.snippet: Far from the land of helicopter parenting, getting ‘dropped’ in the forest is a beloved scouting tradition.
articles.abstract: Far from the land of helicopter parenting, getting ‘dropped’ in the forest is a beloved scouting tradition.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTERLITZ, the Netherlands — Shortly after 10 p.m. on a recent night, a car came to a stop at the edge of the woods. The door opened to release three children: towheaded boys of 12 and 15, and a 12-year-old girl with dark pigtails and an emoji-covered backpack. Then the driver threw the car into gear and sped away, gravel crunching under its tires.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry and Dmitry Kostyukov

articles.headline: Renault and Nissan Need Each Other to Thrive in Future, 2 Leaders Say
articles.snippet: The carmakers must reinvigorate their alliance and share the cost of a shift to electric, self-driving cars, Renault’s chairman and a Nissan board member said in separate interviews.
articles.abstract: The carmakers must reinvigorate their alliance and share the cost of a shift to electric, self-driving cars, Renault’s chairman and a Nissan board member said in separate interviews.
articles.lead_paragraph: A hoped-for merger between Fiat Chrysler and Renault is dead. Long live the Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi Alliance — or else.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing, Liz Alderman and Ben Dooley

articles.headline: Wealth Tax and Free College Get Poll Support. Democrats Worry It Won’t Last.
articles.snippet: Despite the popularity of liberal policy ideas, voters said in interviews that an incremental approach had a better chance of success.
articles.abstract: Despite the popularity of liberal policy ideas, voters said in interviews that an incremental approach had a better chance of success.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a puzzle for the Democratic challengers hoping to unseat President Trump, and it is evident in public reaction to some of their breakout policy ideas.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: Contact Lens Start-Up, Big on Social Media, May Be Bad for Eyes, Doctors Say
articles.snippet: The company, Hubble, offers customers contact lens subscriptions at low monthly prices. Critics say it bypasses eye care professionals, doesn’t properly vet prescriptions and takes advantage of federal regulations to the detriment of consumers.
articles.abstract: The company, Hubble, offers customers contact lens subscriptions at low monthly prices. Critics say it bypasses eye care professionals, doesn’t properly vet prescriptions and takes advantage of federal regulations to the detriment of consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The colorful ads on Facebook and Instagram promise a fantastic bargain: “Stop overpaying for contact lenses. Get 30 contacts delivered to your door for ONLY $1.” Captions like “wow” and “what a steal” splash across images of teal containers and lenses perched on fingertips, urging consumers to act fast.

articles.headline: Jeffrey Epstein Pitched a New Narrative. These Sites Published It.
articles.snippet: In flattering news releases and promotional articles in National Review, Forbes and HuffPost, the disgraced financier tried to rehabilitate his image.
articles.abstract: In flattering news releases and promotional articles in National Review, Forbes and HuffPost, the disgraced financier tried to rehabilitate his image.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Jeffrey Epstein got out of the Palm Beach County jail in 2009, having served 13 months of an 18-month sentence resulting from a plea deal that has been widely criticized, he began a media campaign to remake his public image.

articles.headline: California, Wary of More Wildfires, Is Paying for Them Already
articles.snippet: Anxiety is running high over wildfires this summer, and over the precautionary power cuts that a big utility says will be necessary to prevent them.
articles.abstract: Anxiety is running high over wildfires this summer, and over the precautionary power cuts that a big utility says will be necessary to prevent them.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEARLAKE, Calif. — Two thousand homes lost and two-thirds of the land burned: The residents of Lake County, a sparsely populated area north of Napa Valley, understand better than most the devastating cost of wildfires in recent years.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Ivan Penn

articles.headline: These Michigan Voters Show How Trump’s ‘Go Back’ Attack May Help Him
articles.snippet: Voters in a part of the state that swung for Mr. Trump in 2016 have largely overlooked his recent attacks on four congresswomen, instead focusing their ire on Democrats.
articles.abstract: Voters in a part of the state that swung for Mr. Trump in 2016 have largely overlooked his recent attacks on four congresswomen, instead focusing their ire on Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT HURON, Mich. — As President Trump presses his attacks against four women of color in Congress, suggesting they are unpatriotic and should leave the country, many voters in this city on Lake Huron are embracing his “America — Love It or Leave It” message, saying they do not see it as racist.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Saul and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Equifax to Pay at Least $650 Million in Largest-Ever Data Breach Settlement
articles.snippet: The agreement, which received preliminary approval Monday, would end an array of lawsuits and investigations stemming from the exposure of the sensitive information of more than 147 million people.
articles.abstract: The agreement, which received preliminary approval Monday, would end an array of lawsuits and investigations stemming from the exposure of the sensitive information of more than 147 million people.
articles.lead_paragraph: The credit bureau Equifax will pay about $650 million — and perhaps much more — to resolve most claims stemming from a 2017 data breach that exposed sensitive information on more than 147 million consumers and demonstrated how little control Americans have over their personal data.

articles.headline: With $1 Billion From Microsoft, an A.I. Lab Wants to Mimic the Brain
articles.snippet: OpenAI, now managed by start-up guru Sam Altman, wants to create a machine that can do anything the human brain can do. Skeptics wonder if it is possible.
articles.abstract: OpenAI, now managed by start-up guru Sam Altman, wants to create a machine that can do anything the human brain can do. Skeptics wonder if it is possible.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As the waitress approached the table, Sam Altman held up his phone. That made it easier to see the dollar amount typed into an investment contract he had spent the last 30 days negotiating with Microsoft.
